content:
0, 2014
												If you like food, you must buy.Pros:- Good and upbeat music, great use of sound fx- Delicious looking food, nice visuals, colorful, you can see time change out the window- Has some humor elements that make you chuckle- Many things to do besides cooking (you have to complete chores and catch a burglar)- Very fast paced- You can choose your own menu each day- Each food requires different skills and techniques so it doesn't seem repetitive- Different challenges (catering, making bets with Crazy Dave to complete certain tasks)- Food items are upgradable, you can buy grills/stoves- You can use keyboard, mouse, or controller (prefer keyboard cause it's easier)- Quick and easy tutorials. Lets you test out the food before you buy- The daily buzz element is pretty cool and makes game more realisticCons (seems like a lot but they're minor)- Limited food items to choose from. There's only about 20 something total- Can get stressful during rush hour (but that's what makes it exciting)- Not many things to do once you complete the game (but it takes a while)- Simple gameplay. Place ingredients together by pressing buttons.- Earning money is really slow. You have to work several days in order to buy one item- Cannot customize restaurant- Certain features are never seen. Like buying a dishwasher. You bought it. It decreases the # of times you wash the dishes. But you never actually SEE the dishwasher in the game. Same thing with trash disposal, new toilet, etc.Got the game during summer sale for 3.99. Definitely worth the money. Addictive and fun. Many features in the game makes it realistic (such as serving soup on rainy days will attract more customers, having health inspectors, receiving awkward emails). Pros > ConsA great buy. 10/10 Totally recommended.  Have fun!!!

												Cook, Serve, Delicious is a quite a game. You start with some cash to make a start up resturant buisness, it's a lot of fun for any simulation lover. The game might seem boring at first, but once you get into it, it opens up more. You get to purchase loads of foods, breakfast/lunch/dinner. Later on when you ahieve 2 or so stars you get catering events, and by 3 or 4 you get to be an iron cook. More about the gameplay you use either A. Your mouse, or B. Your keyboard, such as ice cream would be "V" for 1 scoop vanilla, and 'C' would be a cherry. You can also click on the button corresponding to the ingriedent. Lastly it may seem repitive, but once you finish a day (9/10 mins), you may get an email saying, "20% more buzz today," that makes you want to do just one more day. Overall I give the game a 8/10. I would like to see more features added, though.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 16, 2014
												This is one of those games that looks like it has to be either poorly made, or terribly boring. In reality, it's one of the best simulators that I've ever experienced. As you run your restaurant, you're forced to balance pleasing the customers, and pleasing the health inspectors by keeping up with upkeep. All actions are made simple, but not so simple that they can be done without thought. Unlike some games which feature cooking, you're not given simple "Cook" and "Serve" buttons. Instead, you are most often left to assemble dishes with simplified "one key = one ingredient" style combinations (e.g. PSCR PSCR PSCR makes a lasagna [Pasta, Sauce, Cheese, Parmesan]). It's simple in theory, until the lunch rush leaves you hectically trying to push through order after order, all while balancing the need to wash dishes and toss out trash. There's no deep story to the campaign, but somewhat forced menu changes and the always random orders will ensure that days vary heavily and keep you on your toes. Overall, it's well worth the pick up. 8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 1, 2014
												*This is regarding the new update recently. A new game+ feature has been added which gives you a $15,000 starting bonus, all secondary foods unlocked, starts with 6 prep stations, Munchies detractor is disabled, 50% buzz forever, customer count + achivement progress + food pins from your Platinum Star save will be imported (it won't ask you which if you have multiple saves however,) difficulty increase coming from decreased customer patience and Super Rush Hour. Basically even at the start of the new game, you are already on Platinum ++ difficulty with everything on hyper mode. If Platinum wasn't fast enough for you, you'll love new game +. I'm definitely enjoying the difficulty ramp, but at the moment it does look like some combos might be impossible if going for the Perfect Day. Hopefully further upgrades will make such combos possible later in the game. The Good:Ability to rebind keyboard controlsFood effects to prevent boring menuMultiple profiles for different users*Hello there New Game +The Bad:Your stupid datesThe menu to rebind your keys needs some workLack of new game + (no longer applies in the latest update)Cook, Serve, Delicious!, or CSD, is one of the better cooking/restaurant management games I've had the fortune of playing.  Unlike some of your typical games in the same genre, CSD has controls that relies almost entirely on keyboard as opposed to tapping/clicking.  I'm also happy to say I don't have to control a little sprite to deliver food/pick up orders from your customers.  Only thing you need to manage is prepping your food.  Customers will just show up and tell you exactly what they want.  Anything from that point on is just Simon Says with the instructions.  Everything in CSD can almost be played with just your keyboard.  Your mouse is only needed to navigate the menu or turn on/off the music and sound effects in the upper right corner.  All the shortcuts for ingredients can be rebind in the main menu.  It's not the most intuitive interface and does need some work, but it'll get the job done.  I am ok with the default keys for the ingredients, but some people may definitely want to rebind the Onion ingredient's key (it's either O or N on different dishes) and some of the more complex dishes.  I find the food effects in CSD also refreshing.  It prevents the players from using the same menu and stock only the most profitable munchies at all times.Money will be an issue when you start since everything is pretty expensive.  There are times where you'll be offered a chances to "gamble."  It's not really gambling since usually, it's very dependent on your cooking skills and your ability to keep a perfect combo chain going.  The cooking challenges are also a place to rack up some quick cash.  Unfortunately these challenges are one time only until you've maxed your resaurant, but by then I doubt you'd be short on cash.Some potential problems people may have with the game is how repetitive the game can get, since you really are just taking orders and jugggling meat.  20 days to advance to the next level was too long for me.  Usually by 5-8 days I'm fairly proficient at managing chores, customers, and the difficult recipes.  Chores happen in the form of random events.  You need to clean up the garbage, trap the rat, wash the dishes, clean the restroom, and occasionally nab the robber.  The robber happens rarely.  But when he shows up, you can bet that you'll lose your perfect combo streak on higher difficulty.  One thing I also want to nitpick is the dating aspect in the game.  I find it very distracting in the game.  I know it's an optional thing just to get some free gold tickets ($2000 each in the shop,) but everytime your date texts you you are also juggling customer orders.  There's a good chance that you'll lose your combo because your stupid date can't be bothered to text faster or text you after work.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 4, 2014
												reposted from my tumblr: Why CSD is my game of the yearCSD is one of those games that could be called Casual: The mechanics are easy to understand, yet the game manages to keep you busy and engaging, whilst allowing you to adjust the level of challenge in each consecutive playthrough. The way the gmae does this is by allowing you to decide that’s on the days many. The foods that need more prep and cooking allow you to earn more money, but because of the complexity of the preparation and making of the dish, it becomes more difficult to manage over the rush hour periods of the day.Moreover the game even has some light management stuff going on for it: Each day you can change the menu you have to make it include less challenging foods, as well as replace menu items that have begun to rot (i.e. the foods have been on the menu for too long and customers aren’t interested in them). So with these days you might remove one complex menu item and replace it with another to keep yourself fresh in the eyes of customers.There’s also the factor of safety insepctions, robberies as well as bets and stuff that’ll make the gameplay each day more or less hectic.No IAP stuffI like the fact that the game doesn’t make you buy some mooncredits in order to unlock speciality foods like coffee and stuff. No, all the things and all the foods can be aquired by being really clever and good with the menu items. This makes it a fair game, and this paragraph rather poorly written.Should I play this game?In my opinion yes. Even though it looks like a ‘casual’ game, there is a need for good finger dexterity and use of mouse if you are going to keep making wodnerful dishes and making your cutomers happy. There are NO DLC packages released, so you only pay 8.99 euros for the whole game. The game’s simple and easy to understand, and you might even get the cooking bug after playing this game!Final grade:If Mauve is considered to be unpleasant, and purple is the color of exhuberance, i am giving this game a STRONG BEIGE.GOTY of 2013

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 30, 2013
												I've been a fan of Vertigo Games for a long while now, ever since playing their "Ore No Ryomi" game, so it really was not much of a surprise that Mr. Chubigans (founder and primary designer) was planning on making a sequel.The game itself borrows heavily from the PS1 game "Ore No Ryouri" in that it is essentially a simulator of running a restaurant entirely by yourself. No waitstaff, no chef, just you, a kitchen, and a counter full of customers. The game itself is played entirely with the keyboard, selecting first the customer/ticket you wish to service, then hitting the correct keys to process the order correctly.The controls do get a little frustrating at times, but it appears that Mr. Chubigans has added a key binding menu for each dish, so any you have particular trouble with can now be changed. Also, the graphics are impeccably watercolor style, and the music/sound design make this game far more relaxing than you would expect from the time-management genre. Highly recommended for the price!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
0, 2015
												These restaurant-managing sims are a guilty pleasure of mine, and I think this one will keep that part of my brain satisfied indefinitely.  Smoothly polished gameplay, good variety of items to make (all with their own quirks; like having to fry or chop ingredients, and whether you cook at the start, middle, or end of preparation), and a decent amount of fluff around the edges to round out the game.  Also it actually gets seriously challenging.You know how these games work; if not go google "Papa's Burgeria", play for ten minutes, and then come back.  It is a big pile of minigames, and you go through a game-day worth of them at a time.* Includes non-food chores (dishes, trash, etc) that carry special penalties if you fail them* Health inspections, which make the chores harder for a game day* Optional dating minigame; where a special customer shows up, and if you do well on their order they'll text you during work (reading comprehension time trial)* Optional betting minigames, where you take on extra challenges to make more income in a day* At-your-liesure speed/accuracy trials, guised as catering jobs, iron chef competitions, and something hilarious* Upgrade your recipes and restaurant over time, adding new complexities to recipes* Weekly leaderboard challenges* Amusing tidbits to read (fake spam emails, food and event descriptions)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 2, 2016
												A very light simulation composed of a bunch of randomly-ordered QTE-based meal preparation tasks using fun little widgets. You select what food you'll sell today, start the day and then fill the orders as they come in. At the end of the day, you read your 'emails', which give you hints on what may happen the following day. There's a bit of management sim in here, but it's mostly about the QTEs.(Note that the food order QTEs are not particularly complex. There are fewer steps to cooking an item here than in, say, Cooking Mama. Although the complexity does increase the further you get in the game.)The game also boasts some competitive and cooperative modes, an online leaderboard with weekly challenges, etc. I haven't spent much time in those modes yet.Anyways, if that sounds like your sort of thing, I recommend picking it up.

er 23, 2014
												I love Cook, Serve, Delicious! I find myself getting honestly frustrated when I accidentally hit '3' instead of '4' during rush hour and accidentally send off a half-cooked fish, but that's the fun of running a frantically big restaraunt all by yourself. Some orders are going to be mucked up.I agree to some extent that the mechanics get boring. I certainly couldn't finish the whole game in one sitting. In fact, after getting to three stars I became a little unenamoured and stopped playing for a month, only to start craving the fast-paced action and pick it right up again.This is not a game with a story to hang onto but rather a game with addictive mechanics which you will want to come back to again and again. I do still want to upgrade my restauraunt fully, I'm looking forward to seeing the end, but it's the desire to hit the big combos and get a handle on the perfect steak which will bring me back time and time again.

												So, I just finished getting the fabled 5 star rating on my restaurant, (currently going for the elusive Platinum Star) and I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who wants a challenge. Especially since it boosts your ability to multitask, (which definitely helps out with projects or assignments) and challenges your memory, accuracy, and speed. What I LikedThe fact that it boosts your accuracy, speed, and multitasking skill.The amount of gameplay put into the game, which is surprising for this kind of genre of games.The true feeling of finally getting that last star for your restaurant, and just raking in the big money.How fun the extra events and weekly challenges are.What I DislikedHow hard some parts of the Iron Cook episodes are. The slight unresponsiveness of a controller.The fact you need a controller in order to play the game efficiently without any problems.Overall, this game was a very fun time, and was definitely worth the $10 investment put into it. Considering this game still adds new things over time, even if it's not needed. If you want a challenge for once, try out Cook, Serve, Delicious!

												Cook, Serve, Delicious! is a fantastic game that allows you to live out you dreams of being the owner of a successful restaurant. Dive into selecting from a sh*t ton of food choices for service, just so that you can hand make them later during the day. Not only must you make food for the impatient customers but you also have to perform chores throughout service to keep your restaurant clean. A solid 8.5/10 that provides a lot of stupid fun to absorb your time with.

												Really, really addicting arcade-y restaurant sim. There's upgrading and managing the menu between days to keep an attractive menu--not serving the same foods too often, keeping it decently healthy, and such--but the meat of the game is in trying to prepare foods for up to 8 customers at once before they lose patience and without screwing up any orders. content:
er 30, 2013
												I've been a fan of Vertigo Games for a long while now, ever since playing their "Ore No Ryomi" game, so it really was not much of a surprise that Mr. Chubigans (founder and primary designer) was planning on making a sequel.The game itself borrows heavily from the PS1 game "Ore No Ryouri" in that it is essentially a simulator of running a restaurant entirely by yourself. No waitstaff, no chef, just you, a kitchen, and a counter full of customers. The game itself is played entirely with the keyboard, selecting first the customer/ticket you wish to service, then hitting the correct keys to process the order correctly.The controls do get a little frustrating at times, but it appears that Mr. Chubigans has added a key binding menu for each dish, so any you have particular trouble with can now be changed. Also, the graphics are impeccably watercolor style, and the music/sound design make this game far more relaxing than you would expect from the time-management genre. Highly recommended for the price!

er 24, 2015
												This game is for people who really enjoy repetitive/relaxing sim games. You'll be able to tell right off the bat from the gameplay video if you're going to like this or not. People either really like these types of games or they don't.I think where this game really wins, aside from the game as a package overall (really polished, they've added new content and modes over the years, everything is "just right" when it comes to this game) is how well progressed the difficulty is as you play. You won't be making the online leaderboards as soon as you get this game, but damn, you'll be really surprised at how good you get at this game after ~10 hours. And if you like these kinds of games, you will play more than 10 hours. In one day. In one sitting.It has just the right amount of customizability in terms of your controls & menu. The game really makes you want to play it and get really good at it, if that makes sense. And just when you think you're really good, you play the super hard mode and realize how hard this game can get.This isn't a restaurant building sim if you're looking for that. You're not going to get to pick which chairs are in your restaurant and if you want to open a new franchise and hire workers. This is a game for people who enjoy the action of these simulation games rather than the management portion. And I LOVE IT.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 14, 2014
												Cook, Serve, Delicious! is a high octane restaurant sim, complete with typing elements and a whole lot of stress. The game is simple and enjoyable (as long as you can handle making a few mistakes here and there) and is also surprisingly replayable and long for a petty price tag of $9.99.Players are tasked with building up a menu of food items and successfully getting through a day with serving as many customers as possible with a minimal number of complaints. In order to cook the food on the menu, players must either use their mouse or keyboard to assemble all the required components of the item - more complex food (like sushi or salad) require more components, whereas simpler items (like coffee and pretzels) require less components. The player then has to find the perfect balance between high-income food items and low-complexity food items in order to turn a hefty profit and insure that customers don't walk out of the restaurant with an empty stomach. Over time, catering missions, contests and better food becomes available - these make sure that you don't get tired of playing the game after a few hours, and trust me, you won't.The graphics are a simple art style that is neither good nor bad. The music found in the game changes depending on the time of day - Spanish fiesta music plays during the afternoon whereas calm and weary music plays before closing time. There isn't much of a story, except for the goal to constantly improve the restaurant's star rating, but you will find that the game doesn't need one since it is more or less an arcade title.For $9.99, you're going to find that this game is a great deal. I picked it up during the WInter Sale for $4.99 - maybe keep a look out for it in the upcoming Summer Sale if you want to save money. This game could easily serve as a time-killer OR a full-fledged personal favourite, depending on whatever mood you are in. The bottom line however: it's great, buy it and you won't regret it.

content:
er 25, 2014
												I'm a huge sucker for restaurant time management games such as Diner/Cooking Dash, Papa's Gameria series, etc. Out of any restaurant time management games I've played, this one is the most unique.It's highly customizable where you get to pick up to 6 different menu items each with varying difficulty and drawbacks. They can be as stupidly easy as slapping on some condiments and calling it a day, and others are very meticulous as to what order its ingredients need to be in.Needless to say, this game gets super complicated super fast. It's very fast-paced and it gets really hectic later in the game. It makes the game challenging and that's what makes it super fun. Don't think the main game is hard enough? Finish the main game to unlock the New Game+ that is way harder.There are new challenges every week that are ranked against other players, and you can refine your abilities even more with the new Battle Kitchen mode. There's lots to do with this game and it keeps pulling out new features that'll make you want to come back.I highly, HIGHLY recommend this game if you like time management or cooking games. You won't get a game like this anywhere else.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 30, 2014
												Originally I bought the game just to support this game developer, but what I got in return was a game that was extremely addictive, fun and surprisingly hectic and challenging. The game is very well made and even as someone who plays a lot of AAA titles and have a harder time getting into indies, this game sat well with me the minute i started playing. The amount of content this game has for the asking price is astounding. I would have bought it even at $19. What I likedThe Amount of content - It has everything. An email client, competitions, betting, challenges, events, food upgrades, equipments, etcThe game length - I'm 6 hours in as of this review and i have only completed lesser than half of the main game. Even if you are stingy and go by the $1 = 1 hour system, the game would take 12 hours for $10. The thought that went into the game - It is extremely well done and everything is completely different while also linked. From the way you make each dish, to the food boosters and detractors, weather and inspectors. [Personal Opinions] What I didn't likeKey bindings for certain food are too confusing. However, this is an issue related to how a computer works and not the game itself. In a situation like during rush hour, you don't have the time to go through the key bindings for each ingredient. If someone wants a burger with a meat patty and bacon, you would just press "M and B" followed by enter. This could be an issue  when it comes to complex foods with a huge list of ingredients where 2 ingredients would start with the same letter. Take nachos for example, it has multiple ingredients starting with the same letter and during rush hour, when a customer wants nachos with sour cream, you would press "S" only to find out S is shrimp and sour cream is actually "C".  This is a good thing for people who wants a challenge and a bad thing for those who hates remembering key bindings and combos ( like me) . One way to avoid this is to select foods that don't have that many ingredients, but the list shrinks by a lot when you progress the game. And that is all. The game is perfect and is a must buy for anyone who likes a challenge.

Maybe I bought too much equipment too soon -- maybe I splurged on expensive food recipes. I'll never know! It has a good moment-to-moment frenzy, without getting overly stressful or complicated. Maybe I'll get around to it, but... maybe not.I hope more indie games explore cooking as a mechanic. It'd be excellent if Cook, Serve, Delicious were the beginning of a genre.

er 7, 2015
												I used to work in food service, and the first time I saw this, I thought "oh, no. Nonononononononono. It's too real."I'm big enough to admit that I was wrong.For some reason, there's a gigantic, addictive appeal in striving toward that perfect day. You can set the difficulty yourself by choosing a menu full of foods you find easy, or those that make you put your fingers in tiny casts after you've set your computer on fire and then thrown it out the window. And there is something so completely gratifying about committing every different dish to muscle memory; to watching that perfect combo number keep churning upward; to know that even at 179% buzz, you have perfected every order, done every chore, and laughed in the face of that inspector while doing it. You wouldn't think that a cooking sim would give you a rush, but oh god does it.Is it time for CSD2 yet?

content:
y 2, 2014
												Generally a good game but needs improvement.The fast paced nature of the game at later levels really keeps you on your toes with the menu rotting mechanic making sure that you keep switching between foods to keep you from getting too used to certain menu items. The price of improving recipes is a little steep but gives incentive to keep playing however there are some problem areas that need focus on.I encountered two problems while playing this game which has forced me to not include two food items on my menu.1) The soda order of "large cola with ice and fruit blast" 2) The steak order of "everything you have, doubled, except citrus"One of these order maybe a bug, the other is ambigious and in the course of a busy day with 60+ customers when you reach the higher levels, you can't waste time deciding exactly what the order consists of. Whenever i got these orders I fulilled them as i thought i should, large cola with ice and fruit blast but still only got a satisfactory rating from that customer.The steak order could be intepreted as whether to include 1 citrus coating or none at all which doesn't help.Should a sequel be planned, i highly recommend having someone proof read the orders so they are as clear as possible.Other recommended improvements:- Having a back function so if you know you messed up a order, you can go back to the start of that order at the cost of time instead of continuing someone's order, knowing you got it wrong but having nothing you can do about it-When selecting your active menu, having a hover tool tip over each food that shows its modifiers instead of having to keep going to the "buy food" category to see them.This is a good entry in the food sim category, the art is decent and actually makes me feel hungry when I'm playing this on a empty stomach with music that matches the atmosphere of the game that changes depending on rush hour and the time of day which is a nice touch.The game is well designed with a lot of ways to earn extra money while testing your reflexes with a incentive of trying differnt food selections that you may not usually consider having on your money.

content:
er 28, 2013
												I saw this on the autumn sale and thought that it didn't look that good, but had a low price tag so I gave it a shot. In short, you're a cook running a former five star rated restaurant but due to the last years harsh economy it went bankrupt. This is its second life, second chance and you're the sole employee. Because of that you're supposed to prepare all the food, serve it, do the dishes, throw out the garbage and even flush the toilet (!).Besides those chores, you'll be participating in the Iron Chef show and you'll do some catering as well and you'll be "dating" some girls - mainly having their favorite dish on the menu and then doing it in time for them and then answering their texts during the rush hours. Nothing overly complicated, but it's good fun.It is stated that this game is "hardcore", but it's really not. Sure, there is some challenge to it, especially in the later stages, but it's not hardcore what-so-ever. It's more casual if anything, a good time killer. So... if you want a game to fire up when you're waiting for something, then this is the game for you. I recommend it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
4, 2015
												CSD is just hilarious and addicting. Can't really point the finger as to why it's the latter, though. Let's see...On the plus side, it has a decent learning curve (earn money, buy extra food or upgrades). Tasks start out extremely simple, but add up over time. And each menu item handles differently, which acts even more different than the upgraded counterpart. So there's that: a steadily increasing amount of tasks on a time limit. There's no strategy aside from picking the daily menu; anything else is just an attempt at as many perfectly executed tasks as possible.Note that this is a very, very basic game (I bet it would play well on a PC of last century). It has cute graphics, but you'll be too busy staring at the menu orders and the menu lanes to even notice. It doesn't need better graphics either (rather the contrary: it's far more important to be able to directly grasp what to do).The music department does deserve the praise: it may be base elevator music, but it gets stuck in your head after a while. Add to that the basic sounds of you (pretty much literally) throwing food on a platter and you're done. Oh, and of course some praising/disgruntled grumbles from your peeps.As for gameplay...keep in mind that this is NOT a simulator; it's a time management game. It may borrow quite some elements from sim-games, but all purchases, in the end, revolve around time. It's about learning the keys to the tasks by heart (down to pour coffee, 'C' for creamer, tap 'S' for each requested sugar) and execute them well. It's both stress-inducing as relaxing, as the longer you can avoid panic, the better you'll do. So in that area, it doesn't bring much variety to the table and a lot at the same time (some recipes like soup use over half your keyboard). Again: I don't really know WHY I like this game so much, but I do.I have to note, though, that the game is clearly aimed at a touchscreen environment. I haven't played it on android, so can't say if it's easier or harder. Suffice to say that it can become pretty hard. I'm now nearly 20 hours in (I'm amazed...they really flew by!), and I'm still learning and improving. If I'd sent a video of my average 'work day' to myself about 2 weeks ago, I'd say something like "no way I could ever perform that well".Now only to find a real life use. ;-)All in all: a great game. Not for everyone, but at least worth trying. :D

												- "Order number 943, your burger is ready." Anonymous went on flipping his patties, pouring his soft drinks, and laying out the table snacks. As he was pouring a customers drink, the Safety Inspector walked in, acting as if nothing was going on. He forgot! It is day 5 of his new 2 star restaurant, his first inspection of his new restaurant! -Cook, Serve, Delicious is a game that will leave you mad when you fall one order short of that perfect day, or you accidentally cook a fish raw. It will leave you wanting new foods, drinks, and snacks to expand your cooking empire. Grow from a simple 1-star cafe to a 5-star restaurant, with celebrities, VIPs, and the fanciest of the fanciest. You will be begging for more after you get your first perfect day, wanting to get multiple in a row. Cook food, pour drinks, grill fries, bake sandwiches, cook soup, and anything food you can imagine! This is a game that is hard to put down because you want to click that "Start New Day" button just one more time. I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys hardcore, fast-pace cooking. 9/10

content:
r 13, 2013
												This is a time management restaurant sim. What makes it different is the level of depth. Its pretty straightforward as far as the cooking part. Up to 4 people come in and ask for items, and you create it by hitting a selection of keys. IE if someone orders a corn dog, you hit the number displaying that person's request, the dog appears on screen and then you can put ketchup or mustard on it by hitting K or M or both depending on what the person wants. There are complicated items as well, like soups which require many items, chopping and cooking. That part is pretty self explanatory and theres a turorial at the beginning to explain it.It gets really hectic though, because each person will only wait for a limited amount of time for you to start preparing their order or they go away angry. There is a "rush hour" at certain times of the day where all 4 slots fill up fast and are constantly full. I havent found a way to keep everyone happy yet, and that par of the game can get frustrating as hell.There is keybindings to put the most used items grouped together, or however you want to do it. Thats a great feature, because the default is most of the items are listed by their first letter, but some are just random (olives are V, bowtie pasta is w) This can get annoying if much requested food's keys are across the keyboard.The thing that makes this game different is the level of depth of your restaurant management. At the end of every day, a screen pops up where you can buy new equipment and food, check your email, look at your "buzz" (a measure of how well liked your restaurant is). You can also pick the daily menu, upgrade your food , buy things to amuse your customers so they will wait longer and so on. Each food item has boh positive and negative traits like some items are well liked at first, but need to be cycled in and out to keep them "fresh". Some smell good, some are fatty, some are healthy. There are many food items and equipment to choose from, all with different effects. The graphics are bright and cartoony, totally fitting for the flavor of the game. The music (especially the intro song!) is peppy and upbeat, also fitting for the style of game.If you like time management and restaurant sims, this is a great choice to consider. Its hectic at points and can be frustrating, but it is still great fun.

content:
ry 16, 2014
												It's a typing game about food. No, wait, it's a food game about typing.It's Typing of the Dead without the zombies, but with more hamburgers, steaks, lobsters, and cilantro. OK, there's no cilantro. But there's anchovies. And when someone wants them on a pizza, you have to oblige no matter how much it hurts.It's frantic. You're juggling multiple orders while new ones keep coming in in a roughshod attempt to get them all in perfect order. A maintained combo means better pay at the end of the day. Rewards await those who pull off the perfect day. Juggle a menu between highly complicated dishes with expensive prices and easier ones that don't quite make as much. Customize your menu to match the requirements for, and then beat the pants off of, the daily bet. Compete in Iron Che—I mean Cook. Iron Cook, yes—challenges. Grow from a meager hole-in-the-wall diner to a five star establishment, complete with whiny, needy celebrities to indulge!Try to keep up. You won't. You'll try, but you won't. And then, one day, you will. It will be glorious. And all the while you'll have one hell of a time.

content:
6, 2015
												Cook, Serve, Delicious! is a restaurant simulator, or perhaps a line cook simulator, that is ambitious in its reach but somewhat failed in its execution. I'm not talking about the gameplay, which is fun; I'm talking about the bugs. The gameplay reminds me of old coin op serving games with modern twists; instead of pouring mugs of beer or root beer to satisfy customers, each menu item has its own recipe to be followed, many times with multiple steps. The game takes into account time of day (some people get turned off at the smell of fish cooking at breakfast) and weather conditions (rainy days mean comfort food will be popular) as you work to make the money to upgrade your kitchen and buy new appliances. Unfortunately, the game menus are terribly coded so that I could only read roughly a third of the buttons. This includes options menus, food selection, item purchases, upgrades, you name it. If you're not behind the counter making food for customers, there's a two to one chance you won't be able to tell what you're doing. At some point, my control scheme was changed to that for a PS controller without any indication of what key I hit or how to change it back.I really want to like this game. Someday, with proper developer support, it might be worth buying.

content:
er 6, 2013
												So there's basically 3 different categories of food games: waitress (Diner Dash), line cook (assembling orders) and management (you run the resturaunt, hire and fire etc). This game is a combination of a line cook and a management game. It's pretty fast pace and it has multiple side challenges. You play as a line cook who also has to keep up with chores while completeing orders. It sounds overwhelming, and at first it is but eventually you adapt to the gameplay. It's smooth, the graphics fit the game right and I literally feel like this is me running a little food shop by myself. Very fun, 4 hours went by damn quick. I highly recommend, especially if you enjoy food games

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
2, 2015
												Cook, Serve, Delicious! is basically Cooking Mama, but made much more game-y by adding in a simulator layer on top of it. Rather than just play through a series of loosely-related cooking-themed microgames, you manage an entire restaurant, and serve orders in your day-to-day with said minigames. Both the management system and the cooking system are fun, polished, and well thought out. There's lots of things to keep track of, buttons to press, and just enough new twists and mechanics to keep things interesting.There's a lot to love here if you're the type who likes simple, fun games that are more than they initially appear. I highly, highly recommend Cook, Serve, Delicious! if you liked any of the following game franchises:-Cooking Mama-Warioware-Lemonade Stand-Animal Crossing-Harvest MoonPost script: One thing that I'd like to emphasize is that the difficulty scales extremely well. The game starts very simply and rises in complexity and intensity at a rate that I found nearly mirrored my increase in personal skill. I never felt overwhelmed or too bored. I've found that this is an extremely rare thing in video games, so I'm just trying to give credit where it's due.

												This game has no great graphics or music or a complex storyline and it tends to become a bit repetitive, however I found it to be great fun for a few nights. The game will keep your heart bouncing as you will spend most of your time hammering your keyboard and battling against the clock. You won't be typing text, but quickly entering shortcuts in a precise order to prepare food in the game. You will both serve customers and participate in contests. There is a concept of levelling up/upgrading your restaurant and gaining new ingredients/recipes as you get more skilled in preparing dishes. You also need to plan a bit, for you are responsible of managing daily menus where each dish has its pros and cons. Cleaning the bathroom, doing the dishes, taking trash away and some other activities will also interfere with your cooking. Skilled use of the keyboard and high dexterity are the key to success in this game. Simple but hooking!

												I nominated this game for "The “Best Use Of A Farm Animal” Award" because, steak. Steak is definitely the best use of a farm animal. I'm just saying. I expected this game to be more like Cooking Mama, but it's actually a timed-response quick-fire kind of game where you have to quickly tap away at all the necessary tasks to get your orders out correctly and in time. It's more addictive then it seems and there are plenty of gameplay expansion options; it's also a lot trickier to master than you might think. And if you've completed the single player campaign there are lots of other challenges as well as a multiplayer mode. In short, there's a lot more to it and plenty of gameplay you get for the price. The graphics are cute and I hope they get a bit more polish in the future.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
28
												This is a great simulation game! At a first glance, this game looks like it'll be tough as nails. It appears to demand perfection and punish you harshly for mistakes - but the very opposite is true! Your very first items are all very simple to make, and help teach you the base mechanics and buttons of the game. While serving up corndogs and soda might not be the most exciting thing ever, it'll help to automate things like picking up orders and serving them. The difficulty in this game is always determined by the player. If you miss a ton of orders, there will be less customers the next day, allowing you to learn at a slower pace. Additionally, there are many different recipes that vary in difficulty which you can put on your menu to make things easier on yourself. The food all looks great, and is enormously satisfying to make. The sound effects of a burger being slapped together is a feeling like no other, and you will feel like a gaming champion when you reach a perfect day with difficult recipes on your menu.There are a ton of small fun things that the game offers to enhance your gameplay. Some emails and characters will ask for you to carry certain recipes or combinations, gently nudging you to change up your status quo and use recipes that you normally avoid.Becoming good at cooking in this game is satisfying, and it remains fun throughout the entire experience! The only Con I can think of is that the checklist for upgrading your restaurant takes too long to complete. Not because the challenges are demanding, but because it always requires 20 days of gameplay before you can advance. Sometimes this means you need to play through 7-12 days just to advance your restaurant and unlock new upgrades. Also, a few of the recipes can be tricky in their wording, which sometimes leads to frustration and an inability to complete the recipe. ( I'm looking at you, Stacked Enchilada's! ) All in all, this is a great game that I would recommend to anyone. Go for perfect scores on online leaderboards, or just do a few casual rounds trying to perfect that soup recipe you unlocked - it's all fair game!

												Should be called Cook, Scream, Delicious! Because this game will frustrate you. The only thing missing from this game is buying your own groceries.The first play through is very fun, although it can be repetitive you end up changing your menu due to buying new foods, or the weather, or just getting as much buzz as possible. At around 3 or 4 stars, you end up using the same menu. The bets really help change that up, as well as VIPs and dating. The second playthrough, on extreme difficulty, on the other hand could be better. At first, yes it is intense, its hard, but messing up doesn't matter anymore. Making money? You will have tonnes. You will end up making only the easiest foods (fish, chicken, beer, etc.) just so you can get those last few achievements. Lets face it, it gets boring because you get accustomed to it and the star level requirements are exactly the same as on normal. It would be much more difficult and "extreme" as you put it if the requirements to get to the next star was different. Perhaps a buzz % requirement instead, where we are forced to use the more complicated foods to get that buzz. Or have an upgrade requirement on certain foods you must have on your menu? I am getting by the game mode right now with beer, coffee, chicken and fish, alternating them when the other rots. I'm being somewhat forced through almost 100 in game days till I get that mysterious email (estimate as I have not gotten it yet).  It's not fun now, its just a chore.

content:
er 8, 2014
												This is honestly one of the most fun and interesting games I've played in a while. So many little things come together to make it feel fantastic. The aesthetic design is great. The visuals are interesting and varied without being overwhelming, and the sound effects when preparing food make it so satisfying. The soundtrack is also great, and it perfectly fits the tone of the game. There's jazz, funk, samba, all sorts of styles, and all of them can be either driving or relaxing.The game is also well balanced, which may seem like a weird thing to say, but there was never one setup that I knew I could coast through the whole game with. The game makes you change up your menu and buy and upgrade your foods to make it more varied and challenging. And boy, does it get challenging. But it never punishes you for some bs reason. If you get punished, it's because you made a mistake. And since you can arrange your own menu, you only make it as difficult as you want to. Most of the time, anyways. This game is so fantastic, and I cannot praise it highly enough. It may be one of my favorite games. You may not have the same experience as I did, but I would still highly reccommend that you at least try out this game. At $10, it's a great buy.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
y 15, 2016
												Let me contain my gushing and try to do this succinctly. CSD is a restaurant "sim" in the same sense that a bag of potato chips is food. It's quick, accessible, and makes you hungry for more. The core of the gameplay is serving a steady stream of customers via barrages of QTE's as apparently the sole existing employee, in something like Cooking Mama meets Wario Ware on crack -- especially during rush hours. Then, in your downtime between days you get to buy new foods, upgrades to existing ones, bits of equipment, and cycle your active menu to keep your "buzz" level (customer traffic) high. That's as far as the sim portion goes. The old Giant Bomb quicklook with the late great Ryan Davis sums it up well: 


YouTube™ Video: Cook, Serve, Delicious: Giant Bomb Quick Look 

			Views: 44,858		

			Need a cold one at 9:06 AM? Ryan and Jeff have got you covered as they explore the wonders of being restauranteurs. If you like this, maybe you'd like to check out our website!		

 Since release, it's also gotten a slew of free new content including about a dozen new foods, controller support, local co-op and competitive modes, Iron Chef challenges, and more. The dev is pretty active and friendly with the community, and now there's even a sequel on the way.The art is, while largely static, easy on the eyes, while the sound design complements it perfectly and really gives the game its captivating energy. The music is fitting for both the everyday activity and rush hours, and each part of an order you assemble is punctuated by various chops, whacks, slaps, and splashes. I wouldn't change a thing about it.For as much as I love the game, though, it does get off to a frustratingly slow start. The main metric of your progress is accumulating star ratings for your restaurant, which typically require getting a handful of perfect combos, passing a few safety inspections, doing the currently available catering side events... and playing for 20 (in-game) days since your last star upgrade. You will LONG be finished the other requirements by the time this elapses, and getting to 1 and 2 stars is a bit of a drag. On the flipside, though, by the time you get to 3 stars you'll likely be wishing that span was longer, as the game starts to ramp up in challenge FAST. I would strongly recommend you be a competent touch typist if you want to play this!All in all, highly addictive, pretty cheap, the dev's nice, and it's easily earned a spot on my favourites list.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
er 29, 2013
												Cook, Serve, Delicious! by Veritgo Games is a frantic simulation of living the day-to-day life of an up-and-coming sole restaurant owner and operator. While the game may appear to be a simple casual game in a sea of other restaurant managing sims predominantly on mobile platforms, Cook, Serve, Delicious! distinguishes itself by being extremely fast-paced as a chain of frantic Warioware-style mini-games. CSD requires plenty of concentration and muscle memory in order for players to adequately serve their customers.  One point of contention which I rarely see mentioned in reviews for this game is the potentially controversial choice of having players control an alleged murderer and cannibal throughout the course of the game. While not initially revealed, players who take care in reading all of the messages in their email inbox at the beginning of each day are able to piece together the truth to the game's story and find out about all of the people the protagonist has murdered and is trying to dispose of by processing them into delicious delicacies for the enjoyment of the customers of SherriSoda Tower. I feel that is a bit of an odd narrative choice and found it to be a bit unnecessary, but I am happy to report that this revelation did not make the food I was preparing seem any less delicious and did not detract from the enjoyment I had when I finished a hard day's work with a stable of satisfied customers.

												Recommended in the strongest terms. You did not realize that you needed a hardcore cooking sim in your life until you played Cook, Serve, Delicious. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
28
												This is a great simulation game! At a first glance, this game looks like it'll be tough as nails. It appears to demand perfection and punish you harshly for mistakes - but the very opposite is true! Your very first items are all very simple to make, and help teach you the base mechanics and buttons of the game. While serving up corndogs and soda might not be the most exciting thing ever, it'll help to automate things like picking up orders and serving them. The difficulty in this game is always determined by the player. If you miss a ton of orders, there will be less customers the next day, allowing you to learn at a slower pace. Additionally, there are many different recipes that vary in difficulty which you can put on your menu to make things easier on yourself. The food all looks great, and is enormously satisfying to make. The sound effects of a burger being slapped together is a feeling like no other, and you will feel like a gaming champion when you reach a perfect day with difficult recipes on your menu.There are a ton of small fun things that the game offers to enhance your gameplay. Some emails and characters will ask for you to carry certain recipes or combinations, gently nudging you to change up your status quo and use recipes that you normally avoid.Becoming good at cooking in this game is satisfying, and it remains fun throughout the entire experience! The only Con I can think of is that the checklist for upgrading your restaurant takes too long to complete. Not because the challenges are demanding, but because it always requires 20 days of gameplay before you can advance. Sometimes this means you need to play through 7-12 days just to advance your restaurant and unlock new upgrades. Also, a few of the recipes can be tricky in their wording, which sometimes leads to frustration and an inability to complete the recipe. ( I'm looking at you, Stacked Enchilada's! ) All in all, this is a great game that I would recommend to anyone. Go for perfect scores on online leaderboards, or just do a few casual rounds trying to perfect that soup recipe you unlocked - it's all fair game!

content:
7, 2014
												Original March 2014: I bought this on a whim when it was first released on Steam, because I enjoy time management games. This is the most frantic, detailed one I've ever played. It's very easy to succumb to "just one more turn!" over and over again. The game is difficult at first when you're learning the speed and combinations, but you will quickly get the hang of it. I just unlocked my four-star restaurant, and CSD is a game I always look forward to playing. I can't wait to see what else the developer has in store!Update Nov 2016: This is my best random purchase on Steam. I noticed it when it came out, and I really like the Cooking Dash games, so I took a chance. I'm still playing it three years after release, and it's one of my favorite games. Perfect learning and difficulty curve, and the sense of satisfaction when you get a perfect day is awesome. You can easily play a very quick session if you want to (each day only takes about ten minutes), but I often found myself playing for hours. I can't wait for CSD2!

content:
er 27, 2013
												Never have I been a fan of the "Diner Dash" games, but when this game came along it just offers something much more rewarding than those. You still have to manage your customers and give them exactly what you want, but the way you make the meals gives some sense of skill. When dinner rush comes along it's pretty much a frantic mess of making meals and doing chores, and by the time it's over your sweating and glad there is a lull.My one complaint with the game is the progression seems quite slow, you will be doing the same thing for multiple days just to get to the next tier of restaurant quality. There is a few ways they change this up with inspectors, weather changes or food getting boring (which forces you to try different foods), these are a nice change, but still makes it seem like there is a grind.
